web_research.query: What are winning approaches for text classification with meta features on Kaggle, especially for social media data like Reddit posts?
web_research.finding:
Winning Kaggle solutions for text‑classification problems that also contain **meta features** (e.g., post length, subreddit ID, number of up‑votes, time‑of‑day) follow a repeatable recipe: first turn the raw text into a fast, high‑quality vector (fastText embeddings or TF‑IDF weights), then concatenate any engineered numeric descriptors and feed the combined matrix into a powerful gradient‑boosting or linear‑model stack.  This hybrid approach lets the model exploit both the semantic signal of the language and the auxiliary information that often drives the target label in social‑media settings such as Reddit posts ​([Result 1](https://neptune.ai/blog/text-classification-tips-and-tricks-kaggle-competitions)).

The most common building blocks observed in top Kaggle notebooks are:

* **FastText “bag‑of‑tricks”** – a simple word‑n‑gram embedding that trains on billions of words in minutes and delivers accuracy comparable to deep‑learning baselines while keeping the feature matrix small eno
